												As far as I'm concerned, this is the best game ever - especially in this version with the first two additions to the game.To a certain extent, it is comparable to the Total War games, if they only included the map mode, which would here be simplified to armies only being able to move from province to province and not within a province. However, you have a more complicated diplomacy and domestic policy to deal with.Another thing that makes it different, and, for my taste, better than the Total War games, is the greater realism and historical accuracy - in this game you can't just conquer everything, and it remains challenging for the more than four centuries that its timespan covers.The fact that the game never becomes "too easy" is what makes it so good: You know early on that you want to make the country as which you are playing as successful as possible and to that end, you have to position it so it can rise to the challenge while always remaining watchful for your rivals.Some (minor) things which might make the game a little less enjoyable are the huge random factor in battles - one of the factors that determine a battle outcome to a sometimes massive extent is the game literally casting a dice, which might be a little frustrating sometimes, especially when your and your opponent's armies are roughly equal. Precisely this is also the next minor annoyance in the game: Armies are quite often equal, aside from their exact size, as you do not have a lot of options in structuring your military - which, while rather straightforward and easy to understand, is a bit disappointing, as the game's focus, while definitely present in diplomacy, trade, colonisation and policy, is still mainly conquest.Also, and this has more to do with the store page than the game, I'm almost sure some of the screenshots are not from the version that is sold here, but from a version where one or both of the further DLCs (which are not included in the "complete" version) are installed.All in all, a definite buy, as long as you are into (grand) strategy games, and don't need a game to be too action-laden.EDIT: As I've now bought all the DLCs to this game, I am now rather certain that some of the screenshots on the store page aren't from this game at all, but rather from Europa Universalis IV, which would definitely be an avoidable mistake on Steam's side.

												Whee. Europa 3, like its predecessors and its cousins Hearts of Iron and Victoria (Crusader Kings as well, but that isn't as hard to learn), is an extremely complex game that is notoriously difficult to learn, not helped by crappy tutorials. I had an edge having been playing this series since its first installment, but it still took some time to get used to everything. So right from the start expect a significant time investment on learning how to play the game, and learning to do well at it. War, Diplomacy, Trade, Exploration, and more. It's all here.But it is worth it. Oh yes is it worth it. EU3 is a -gigantic- game with near-endless replayability and a player-driven storytelling ability (creating a story from your own experience of playing the game) in the same league as the Civilization and Sims games. You can play as any country in the world, though the game is a bit euro-centric considering the time period it covers (1399-1821) is the period in history when Europe came to dominate most of the rest of the world. Those who know their history also know that there is a MASSIVE amount of stuff contained in this time period: The fall of Byzantium and the rise of the Ottoman Turks, Columbus' voyage to America and the mass colonizing that followed, The Protestant Reformation and the horde of religious wars that came with it, Independence movements in the "settler colonies" of the Americas, and finally the French Revolution that leads to a gigantic war at the end of the game.However, little to nothing is set in stone. Byzantium might not fall. The Spanish may not be the ones to build a massive American colonial empire. The Protestant Reformation might just be a tiny local event, and the French Revolution might not even happen in France or at all. In other words, there is considerable variation, and much of that can be the result of the player's actions. Events can follow history or lead to an entirely different result. I've seen just about everything happen while playing this game from the Aztecs never being conquered, the Ottomans being extinguished early on (or built into the kind of monster empire you can see in my screenshots), Spain never being united as a single country, and so much more. And if you are a masochist of the highest order, you can try to take over the world as the Ryukyu Kingdom (Okinawa).How will things go? It is up to you to see. :)

												Europa Universalis III is a grand strategy game and a part of one of the most renowned empire building strategy franchises of all time. EUIII gives you control over a nation of your choosing (and there is plenty material to choose from) and absolute strategic freedom to assemble your future world hegemon. This game combines a perfect balance between all areas of strategy (such as depth of war tactics, exploration, diplomacy, religion and government structure), as well as makes sure all of those stated above are realistic. Don’t expect to have an easy time defending against a Great Power with a minor. The game also introduces a lot of historical aspects into it, such as the great people of the time, geographical accuracy and random historical events, that will give you some unique experience with each new nation you play. And I’m not talking about difficulty, exactly, although EUIII has enough of that. If you are a kind of person who enjoys a lot of details and thought put into management of your country, dynasty and international stance, etc. – then EUIII would clearly be a preferable choice for you. However, if you prefer a smooth and dynamic gameplay, then, in my opinion, EUIV does have an advantage in that regard. Once again, I own both games and both are pieces of game art, but I just thought it was important to put this out there. Enjoy the game.

												Paradox have a fantastic collection of history based Grand Strategy Games. Think 'RISK' with a little bit of politics, and that's what you're going to get from Europa Universalis III. Those going in expecting amazing graphics and detailed animated battles will be disappointed, as it's simply not _that_ game. Fights are math/dice roll based, which take into account unit type, general, terrain, etc so there is depth in the battles. However, visually they are represented by single unit graphic, numbers, and literally dice rolls. I don't mind this, as it suits the desk top game nature that I've come to admire from the Paradox Clausewitz Engine. Once you overcome this the games become incredibly indepth, with various scenerios based on history appearing throughout the game. You can either follow them as we know them, or change the course of history.To give you an idea of the scale the game can potentially last over the course of 400 years (if you have all the expansions) from 1399-1821. So you can start at the end of the 'Hundred Year War' and finish around the time of 'Napoleon' with all the history in between.The latest DLC 'Divine Wind' adds the Far East to EUIII (Japan & China). I haven't had a chance to fully test out this area of the game yet, but it sounds detailed and exciting. If you enjoy Empire Building (and a slight Dynasty building element), and don't mind a lack of detailed animations to keep your attention span, then this game might be for you. There's a good thread on GAF, which has plenty of helpful people to help you understand what's going on - http://www.neogaf.com/forum/showthread.php?t=466864

Go play Pac Man or Streetfighter or some other button masher, because this game will just hurt your wittle feelings.   It's old. And once you have a firm grasp of the mechanics you'll be orchestrating Machiavellian plots that will bring massive swathes of the world under your evil (let's just face it you warmongering bastage) grasp.  If you can master the mechanics of this baby you're well on your way to being a fully qualified field marshall of strategic gaming.  I highly recommend this game to anyone just getting into Paradox's line of strategy games.  It's a far more refined product than it's successor game EU 4 is at this point.10 out of 10 and you can take that to the bank.

Posted: March 27, 2013
												The monolithic historical simulator from Paradox gets a makeover with lessons learned from Victoria, Crusader Kings and Hearts of Iron. The most noticeable improvement from EU2 is the 3D graphics and polished interface. The graphics don’t do as much for the look of the game as much as it simplifies the look of the map. Gone is that “boardgame” feel of EU2 as land, cities and armies have more of an organic feel to them rather then just being markers.A great new improvement is national ideas. By specializing your country in certain aspects of warfare, trade, exploration and colonization or religion, you can get your goals accomplished easier. What is interesting is you will see some nations choose some very ahistorical ideas. In other words, imagine Poland recruiting conquistadors to colonize Central America. (Would they even be called “conquistadors?”)The AI in EU3 is considerably harder and smarter. If you post an army at a neighbor’s border, don’t be surprised if he does the same. Beyond warfare, allies will betray you, rivals will rush to colonize the best provinces, and nations will band together to stop your expansion.Overall, EU3 just plays differently than its predecessor. Random events aren’t as “random” as before and every choice you make effects the decisions you will make in the future. This makes the game play along more natural storylines.The retail version comes with a beautiful 145 page manual that describes pretty much all you need to know to play a game. The tutorials will help you navigate the interface but the majority of learning comes from playing the game itself.

Posted: March 24, 2016
												Map Painting Simulator. If you love map painting, then this game is for you - all the politics in Europa Universalis III is about one ultimate goal: Annihilate everyone until you are the only one left or you get bored and start all over, preferably as a different country. Some countries are better represented, other are just there to exist and perish, but overall there are enough interesting states to provide a huge amount of gameplay, especially with all the add-ons. Unfortunately, for me this game is a rather bland experience. I would vote "average" if it was possible on Steam, however, it is not. This is the worst series that comes from Paradox studio, because it doesn't provide any internal politics like Crusader Kings, nor any interesting economics and population control like Victoria. The wars are not as detailed and do not require much thinking either, this isn't anything like Hearts of Iron, where the player is challenged and has to adapt to the changing war and apply appropriate tactics. Europa Universalis III is just about attacking smaller country and overrunning it quickly with army, taking it over and repeating the same thing all the time. It has other elements of gameplay, but nothing of importance. Unlike other Paradox games EU III doesn't focus on any particular aspect of running a country, hence it is quite void of content and feels bland. I would recommend playing Victoria II, Crusader Kings 2 or Hearts of Iron III over Europa Universalis III, depending on what exactly are you looking in such a game, because EU III has nothing special about it.

												Being from 2007, this game looks TERRIBLE. There are crashing issues as well.Also, this game is not great. Lots of clicking to get simple things done or to get information that should be readily apparent.Recruiting units is a pain: Click province, click unit button, click unit. Click next province, click unit button, click unit. Click next province, click unit button, click unit... on and on ad nauseum. You have to click on individual armies and open up a dialogue to see how large they are. There is no indication for this on the campaign map. Good luck keeping everything straight. Oh, and good luck selecting a fleet, instead of the port it's next to; or not pulling your hair out trying to get just the ships you want out of a group of fleets (group select, and then individually close each individual fleet you don't want... instead of being able to simply select the one you do want).Oh, and nations are not labelled on the political mapmode... what's with that? They're color coded, but if you want to see who that is, you have to click on one of their provinces and hope you didn't actually select one of their neighbors who's a slightly different shade of yellow. Again, good luck keeping anything straight. Trade and diplomacy are similarly inscrutable. They have mapmodes, but centers of trade are not labelled, and there's no visual indication of how trade flows from one place to another; unless you open individial trade center menus and learn to read them. Not for the faint of heart or the casual player. Basically... skip this one. The only reason I played it at all is that EUIV has trouble running on my machine and I can't afford an upgrade just yet. But even if this were the newest outing... there are a lot of gaps where any game dev who was giving it serious thought might easily have tripped over a better solution than what they have implemented.

The game does suggest you choose from a subset of nations that were worked out in detail, but the game feels so well made that it isn't impossible to play as another nation.The AI of a strategy game is always extremely important. It does suffer from predictability in the diplomatic department, and sometimes decisions that don't make strategic sense can only be explained through game statistics (example: "Ah, I see, they hate me and they can't see my armies so they attack me even though it's not in their best interests." or "Their war weariness is quite high so even though I entered the war on their side they still accept a disadvantageous peace almost immediately."), but on the whole it is very satisfying to ally with or fight against.Where this game shines most is in the multiplayer department. This truly is the new Risk as far as I'm concerned, but better, much better. Convince your playgroup to play this for a few hours each week and you won't be disappointed.Some might be bothered by the fact that there is no real goal and thus no real winner, but I actually adore that aspect, it is a matter of taste. Some might be bothered by the lack of tactics (battles are fought mostly by statistics and dice rolls), but the strategic depth is such that I firmly believe that was a wise decision from the developers. And some will be bothered by the lack of flashy graphics. The look is purely functional, and the interface with all the menus and buttons already felt archaïc the moment this game was released.
